title: Monday, 3rd September 2018
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Hello! Welcome, hi there, good morning.

Blank canvas welcome back
wayneJ A refreshed, recharged BE!
Soundbuy Morning all..........

Hope you all had a decent break. Glad to say that the fortnight passed without the need for an emergency session.

BE11:05am

Good also to see the readership turning up on the right, in spite of my failure to do a "we're back on air" type post this morning.

Manxish Morning each

AlexST Dechra Pharma - any more details on the move this morning ?

11:14 am
BE11:14am

“We had simply run out of cash,” he recalls, as we sit on a vintage sofa at Oliver headquarters in north London nine months later. “And we hadn’t expected it. That is just not normal, in any business. You have quarterly meetings. You do board meetings. People supposed to manage that stuff should manage that stuff.”

BE11:14am

Hm.

Excel Developer Hiya
BE11:15am

Perhaps would've been more up to speed if he'd talked to anyone even vaguely connected with the industry over the previous month or so, because the rumour was absolutely everywhere.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

But anyway, back to Citi.

BE11:16am

We see 2 major risks ahead from a potentially disorderly Brexit process and the increasingly indebted nature of UK consumers. Our UK economists have pointed to up to 5pp slower growth in GDP over the 2-3years following a disorderly Brexit. When combined with the increasingly indebted nature of UK households this suggests to us that there could be meaningful downside risks to forecasts.

Patience @wayneJ - the Ruritania of Africa? :-)
BE11:17am

Also cites the recent ONS report on credit: https://www.ons.go...irmeans/2018-07-26

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Showing households have become net borrowers for the first time since 1988 and that the poorest 10% of households already spend two-and-a-half times their disposable income.

Excel Developer Record highs for SP500 over last fortnight I think.
Tom Dalgleish @Wayne, u mean hold a mortgage?
BE11:18am

So ...... we're doing "squeezed middle" again.

wayneJ I find it increasingly amusing that the Brexiters (eg on Sunday TV) talk about how it is important for the UK to trade with the rest of the world because that is where future forecast growth is; I assume this forecast is based on economists' models. Yet when asked about the impact of a hard Brexit they dismiss economists models.
BE11:18am

While special event dining will continue to support the high end and the structural growth in fast food and delivery will continue to support the low end of the market many listed operators risk being squeezed in the middle ground. Restaurant capacity is finally contracting (-0.4% in the last 12months) but CVA mechanisms are preventing a full scale shake out and in our view extending the pain.

Excel Developer "Our UK economists have pointed to up to 5pp slower growth in GDP over the 2-3years following a disorderly Brexit. " So does that mean 5/100ths knocked off growth? ... that is nothing surely.
11:18 am
BE11:19am

Then we have debt. Still too much of it.

wayneJ @Tom - I nearly wrote that the UK equivalent would be student loans plus mortgages etc but then refrained myself
BE11:19am

We continue to believe that many of the operators have too much leverage and importantly little surplus cash flow with which to de-lever. As a result some operators are left in precarious state. Without a sharp improvement in consumer prospects it is hard to see how investors can look forward to stronger earnings or deleveraging, leaving limited prospects for share price performance.

Excel Developer @waynej: restrained (surely)
wayneJ @Excel - yes - I stand corrected
Excel Developer Blowout figures for Japanese Cap Ex overnight... https://uk.investing.com/economic-calendar/capital-spending-32
Excel Developer 12.8% japan capex doubling forecast 6.6%
BE11:21am

Spinning forward to 'spoons .....

Excel Developer what is japanese for gangbusters?
11:21 am
BE11:21am

The group’s best in class earnings growth has driven a sharp rerating relative to peers. Assuming a normalization of LFL growth and allowing for modest margin contraction we expect EPS growth to be more in line in the next 5 years as a result we see downside risks to the multiples. We value the company at an average of our EV/IC (784p), DCF (1,009p) and Multiples (920p) methodologies deriving a target price of 970p (was 1,420p).

BE11:22am

M&B goes up to neutral on valuation, everything else sell except Greene King and Restaurant Group, which are buys on valuation.

BE11:22am

That's the gist of that.

11:22 am
undefined
BE11:23am

Oh, you may as well have Berenberg on Restaurant Group as well. Since we're here.

BE11:24am

The Restaurant Group faced another very challenging period in H1 2018, with EBIT declining by 21% yoy. The casual dining business is clearly still struggling and we think its profitability will continue to come under pressure. However, the company is trying to offset underlying weakness with new concessions-contract wins and acquisitions of pubs. We still have serious concerns about the sustainability of the casual dining restaurants but, given the company will likely be able to continue expanding the better-quality divisions, we see fewer imminent negative catalysts so upgrade to Hold.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

"casual dining business contributes only 49% of site EBITDA" says Berenberg, which is surprising.

BE11:25am

Suggesting much of the high street business is operating at or below breakeven.

BE11:25am

Though, given how aggressively they price on Groupon and the like, that might not be a huge surprise.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

BE11:26am

https://www.groupo...izza-steak-burgers

BE11:26am

Back to Berenberg.

jmcs That does not seems agressive, but desperate, I guess
11:26 am
BE11:27am

While the profit split paints a worrying picture for the casual dining brands, it suggests the pubs and concessions account for more profit than we previously believed. Thus, as those divisions expand, we see a scenario where new sites contribute enough to offset any further disappointment from the casual dining business, which has already seen a significant decline. Much of the growth in pubs is coming from acquisitions, with 15 sites added through the purchase of Ribble Valley Inns and Food & Fuel in the last few months. Although this has caused leverage to rise slightly, we estimate the company will end 2018 with GBP64m net debt and it has a GBP140m debt facility. As such, it has plenty of capacity to acquire more pubs.

Tom Dalgleish 53 quid a touch high non?
BE11:27am

12.9x 2019E P/E for a 3% 2019-21E EPS CAGR, says them.

wayneJ What is interesting about that Groupon page is that it claims 1000+ bought TODAY!!!??

wayneJ And 3,979 ratings - assuming say 1 in 5 to 1 in 10 provide a rating (others may correct - not sure if Groupon requires compulsory ratings) I would hestitate to suggest that rather a lot of footfall is going through Groupon???
BE11:28am

So ........... what else? Dechra mentioned.

Dechra Pharmaceuticals PLC (DPH:LSE): Last: 2,650, down 470 (-15.06%), High: 3,066, Low: 2,454, Volume: 709.47k
11:29 am
BE11:29am

FY results fine, outlook weak.

BE11:30am

RBC has the best of the summaries.

BE11:30am

FY18 results in line with consensus, representing a good year but missed our top-end expectations. Within the statement there are a number of one-off and
underlying points that lead us to believe consensus in outer years could come down c.3-5% in FY19E and c.6-8% in FY20E. Whilst the fundamentals remain
largely in place for the longer-term outlook, we think the shares could come under pressure today given the strong run and if downgrades do come through. We
look to the analyst presentation to understand more on key risks (customer consolidation and distributor risk) before updating numbers ourselves.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Against our expectations Dechra has reported a 2.9% miss at EPS (albeit in line with consensus) with the underlying EBIT margin not as high as we had hoped
(3.7% miss at EBIT) and offset by lower interest costs. With revenues pre-reported at the trading statement there were no surprises by division at the top line
(+8.3% underlying growth for the Group) but the Group gross margin was c.82bps light and then the NA Pharma business saw higher costs, which led to a
9.0% miss against our divisional EBIT expectations (3.7% at the group level). Standing back, we must remember that FY18 has not been a bad year for Dechra,
EBIT growth +21.9%, EPS +18.3% growth, but with this driven by acquisitions (organic EBIT was +9.7%) and, one could argue, priced in at current levels. From
the statement we understand that management have invested heavily in the US business, which delivered a strong top line (+18.2% growth), but this top line
growth was slightly weaker than we had as management withdrew products in Mexico and the top-line growth may now slow as key products reach peak share
and risks grow.
On the outlook, we would note from the risk section and highlights in the statement we have confirmed with management that there are a number of headwinds
which could lead to consensus downgrades of c.3-5% in FY19E EPS and 6-8% to FY20E EPS (perhaps in spite of a c3-4% currency tailwind at current rates).
Whilst some of these are uncontrollable (Brexit and Iran sanctions with management acting accordingly), we see underlying/growing risks as well detailed in the
statement that are likely to add to the former. Whilst the fundamental appeal of Dechra hasn’t changed materially, consensus downgrades on a name currently
trading on c36x FY19E EPS and an EV of 21.6x EBITDA (assuming downgrades come through) and 1.9x levered at end-FY18 will be tough to swallow for
some. We had been concerned that the shares were overheating and that investors were not factoring in potential risks (customer consolidation and distributor
copycat/generic launches, in particular), so we think they could come under pressure. We look to see the scale of share price move to see if this presents an
opportunity.

Forester @wayneJ Indeed. And at that kind of discount, anyone other than out-of-towners or tourists would be made to walk into the place and pay full whack. 10% discount I could not be bothered with but 63%........

BE11:42am

Everyone else, not so much.

BE11:42am

Liberum incoming.

Tom Dalgleish @BE, on the construction of LFL there is a retailer here that excludes old stores into which territory is has started a competitor for 2 years. Thereafter resuming at the new (lower) base
11:42 am
BE11:42am

Downgrading for the second time this year is highly disappointing. Delays to new store openings and upsizes mean these are unlikely to contribute much ahead of Christmas. When combined with a tough backdrop leading to higher promotional activity, higher costs and the knock-on impact from a tough H1, results in a 64.4% cut to our FY19E EBITDA. The company remains committed to the capital projects laid out at the prelims, which sees capex of £16m this year but a lower rate of openings in the outer years. However higher deprecation, and interest impact overall earnings. The group should hopefully start to see the benefits from some of the initiatives laid out by the Executive Chairman but these take time to deliver. Until then visibility on earnings is low and the rest of FY18/19E is likely to be difficult. For now, we keep our target price and recommendation under review.

Tom Dalgleish so same store sales are not for the same stores
BE11:43am

Liberum and Altium floated this thing, to remind.

BE11:44am

GCA Altium as Nomad and Liberum in to rattle the stick in the bucket.

11:44 am
undefined
BE11:45am

While in smalls, Safestyle

BE11:46am

Which has reached a settlement with SafeGlaze, the company set up by its co-founder.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Do read Kate Burgess here for full details of the tragi-hilarious tale: https://www.ft.com...-bf9e-8771d5404543

BE11:47am

Here -- once again -- is Liberum to take us through what's been announced in the settlement, much of which is confidential.

BE11:47am

Under the settlement, SafeGlaze will be rebranded and its behaviour towards Safestyle representatives restrained. Safestyle might have won damages by taking the case to a full hearing but the case was still at least a year away and would have been costly to pursue. We believe that Safestyle is well placed to compete with this new entrant now that it has a level playing field, and expect new management to stabilise the business and start to restore profitability. There is considerable upside in the shares if recovery can be delivered, and we await confirmation that this is underway with interim results on 20 September.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

[W]e understand that its new name will eliminate any scope for confusion between the two companies. The settlement also governs the relationship between the two companies in future, mainly preventing any intimidation or harassment of Safestyle representatives. This should mean that in its new form SafeGlaze will become a normal new entrant to the replacement window market, whereas until now it had been very aggressive towards Safestyle, in particular poaching a significant number of representatives from Safestyle. We believe that Safestyle is well placed to compete against this new entrant now that there is a level playing field, because it has the lowest cost production facilities and a strong brand that can be restored quickly.

BE11:49am

So ......... never mind that Safestyle didn't win damages, it's the level playing field that matters.

BE11:49am

We are forecasting a loss before tax of £3m in 2018, which compares to peak (2016) PBT of £20m. We believe that there is significant recovery potential as Safestyle replaces employees poached by SafeGlaze and market share starts to be recovered and grows once again. This remains a very fragmented industry, with Safestyle having around 11% market share and competitors 2-4 (Anglian, Everest and Safeglaze) having 15-20%. We remain convinced that Safestyle has a cost advantage in manufacturing, which should enable momentum in market share to be turned positive once again.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

We note that the Group made EBITDA of £15.7m in 2013 when sales were £125m; and we expect EBITDA of -£1m in 2018E from sales of £124m. This shows the scale of the recovery potential.

wayneJ @Tom - wow. I assume it was FOOT you were referring to?
BE11:50am

The shares look very cheap at 40p and we believe they could rise to 80p on a two year view (10x PER 2020E) if the stock market starts to have confidence in the 2020E estimates.

BE11:50am

We also highlight that at 40p the shares only trade at around 2x peak earnings, suggesting very considerable upside if management can successfully rebuild the business to previous levels of activity.

Tom Dalgleish In Oz its Dominos Pizza. Could be parallels there
11:50 am
BE11:50am

We continue to expect a small net cash position at year end [£0.3m] which should rise as profitability is rebuilt.

undefined

11:52 am
BE11:53am

Not a lot in the weekend press beyond backing into the Whitbread story.

Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 4,550, down 46 (-1.00%), High: 4,687, Low: 4,546, Volume: 334.93k
wayneJ @Tom - thx.
BE11:54am

And I was on a beach in sunny Fife so missed the drama. The Coke-Costa deal didn't leak at all, did it?

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Anyway, upshot now is that Costa's gone at 16x EBITDA

Tom Dalgleish The UK being awash with struggling food outlets could be a harbinger. Already some listed franchisors cannabalise the franchisees
BE11:55am

And Elliott "looks forward to continuing to engage with the company to maximise the value of the remaining businesses"

Tom Dalgleish BE not into the share price
BE11:56am

Suggesting that Elliott wants Premier Inn sold too, which'd leave Whitbread a very small collection of crap pubs.

Tom Dalgleish Ah Fife. Beautiful Fife
11:57 am
BE11:57am

However, this ain't easy. Morgan Stanley's Jamie Rollo is, as always, excellent.

BE11:58am

Premier Inn is unique in having both substantial domestic scale and also substantial real estate, a function of its UK brewing pub heritage. By contrast, the global hotel operators now mostly only manage or franchise third party hotels, and most European asset heavy hotel operators are relatively small. In addition, the large global players are relatively small in the UK (e.g. Premier Inn is 3-7x as large as Holiday Inn, Hilton or Marriott), and the hotel industry is fragmented. Continued commentary by activist investors Elliott Advisors and Sachem Head for further "value optimisation", as well as Q&A on the call covering the company's future options, mean a key market debate is whether the Costa disposal could lead to Whitbread aligning its business model with peers by separating its real estate and or take part in consolidation.

Flaneur Ah yes the old match of the day line - Forfar 5 - Fife 4...
BE11:58am

Whitbread want to retain the real estate, of course.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

MOST considers all possibilities here and figures .....

BE11:59am

First, splitting the Hotel business would risk losing the structural benefits listed above that PI enjoys from full control of its product (brand, operations, property). Second, these three businesses have very different characteristics so would appeal to different owners, requiring a 3-way split, which would be complex. Third, the highest quality element of the hotel value chain is the brand / franchise value, but this is only 10-15% of total value, so to break a business up to extract a small part risks the tail wagging the dog, and the overall value is still heavily reliant on the value of the real estate and opco.

Tom Dalgleish There was a radio show here consisting of all UK soocer results. Lives turned on it. Before Premier League glamorised it
BE12:00pm

Argues instead that a sizeable acquisition in Germany may make more sense.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

If Germany needs to represent, say, 20% of UK Hotel EBIT to be on investors' radar, this implies ~40k rooms there [vs its UK 70k rooms], but we estimate this would either take time [25 years if expansion is organic], or significant investment (a c. £2bn acquisition assuming a generous 8% post-tax ROCE). However, a transaction of this scale could impinge on the plans to return a "significant majority" of the Costa proceeds to shareholders, or would require it to issue equity (potentially dilutive with its current valuation multiple well below where private transactions have traded).

BE12:01pm

You know what'd be hilarious?

Excel Developer @BE: thanks for groupon tip. A new favourite web site for me now.
BE12:02pm

It'd be hilarious if Whitbread did a special div on the Costa proceeds, then pulled a massive acquisition that was rights issue funded and Elliott ended up having to either back that or get diluted.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Okay, maybe not hilarious. But something.
